images.alt: Pearl Semiconductor specialises in advanced timing integrated circuit (IC) solutions for next-generation AI infrastructure.

images.alt: Founder and CEO of Pearl Semiconductor, Ayman Ahmed.

items.content:
[The content of this article has been produced by our advertising partner.]
A new wave of industrial growth is taking shape as the manufacturing of AI infrastructure products enters a period of rapid expansion. Fuelled by the rollout of next-generation data centres and high-performance computing systems, specialised production is expected to accelerate through 2030, transforming global supply chains and elevating technological capabilities worldwide. With AI infrastructure investments projected...

items.title: Chinese vacuum maker using Temu’s playbook dreams big with Super Bowl debut
items.creator: Coco Feng
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Chinese vacuum maker using Temu’s playbook dreams big with Super Bowl debut

images.alt: The commercial is a statement of commitment, according to Dreame. Photo: Handout
images.title: The commercial is a statement of commitment, according to Dreame. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Robot vacuum maker Dreame Technology promoted its products at the Super Bowl on Sunday night, becoming the latest Chinese brand after Temu to leverage the game’s influence to crack the North American market.
Its 30-second commercial, aired across NBC’s local affiliate network, which exclusively broadcasts the game, showcased Dreame’s ecosystem, from robot vacuums and lawnmowers to a concept hypercar unveiled at the CES trade show in Las Vegas last month.
The campaign follows budget shopping site...

items.title: Pony AI and Toyota roll out mass-produced robotaxis in China’s autonomous drive push
items.creator: Daniel Ren
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Pony AI and Toyota roll out mass-produced robotaxis in China’s autonomous drive push

images.alt: The roll-out is an important step forward for Pony AI in commercialising autonomous cabs worldwide. Photo: Handout
images.title: The roll-out is an important step forward for Pony AI in commercialising autonomous cabs worldwide. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Chinese self-driving technology firm Pony AI has started mass production of a robotaxi co-developed with Toyota, taking an important step forward in commercialising autonomous cabs worldwide.
The Guangzhou-based company said on Monday that 1,000 driverless cabs of this kind would roll off the production line this year, to be deployed in top-tier mainland Chinese cities. The cars will reinforce Pony AI’s plan to operate a total robotaxi fleet of more than 3,000 units in various mainland and...

items.title: Insta360, Vivo challenge DJI’s turf, eyeing a slice of the gimbal camera boom
items.creator: Iris Deng
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Insta360, Vivo challenge DJI’s turf, eyeing a slice of the gimbal camera boom

images.alt: Visitors at the Insta360 booth during BILD Expo 2025 at the Javits Center in New York City. Photo: Getty
images.title: Visitors at the Insta360 booth during BILD Expo 2025 at the Javits Center in New York City. Photo: Getty

items.content:
Chinese electronics companies Insta360 and Vivo are preparing aggressive moves into the gimbal-stabilised camera market, setting up a direct challenge to DJI’s dominance, though analysts warn the newcomers may struggle to match the drone maker’s entrenched content ecosystem.
Insta360, a key rival to GoPro, is planning a handheld gimbal camera aimed at DJI’s popular Pocket series, currently slated for release in the first half of the year, according to people familiar with the matter.
Separately,...

items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: ByteDance’s new model sparks stock rally as China’s AI video battle escalates
items.content:
TikTok parent ByteDance’s pre-release of its latest artificial intelligence video model, Seedance 2.0, over the weekend has sent ripples across the tech and video production sectors as competition among Chinese tech titans’ AI apps intensifies.
The model – still in beta and available to select users of Jimeng AI, ByteDance’s AI video platform – delivered enhanced lifelike video outputs that blurred the boundary between AI content and reality, offered smoother camera movement and improved visual...

items.title: M&A market ‘firing on all cylinders’, headed for record year, Citigroup says
items.creator: Aileen Chuang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: M&A market ‘firing on all cylinders’, headed for record year, Citigroup says
items.content:
The mergers and acquisitions (M&A) market is expected to have its best year ever, with artificial intelligence dominating activity despite recent volatility in technology stocks and broader jitters across assets, according to senior investment bankers at Citigroup.
Market participants worldwide faced a repricing in the digital economy and a wave of sell-offs across tech stocks, commodities and cryptocurrencies last week as investors grappled with the implications of AI. However, the turmoil...

items.translated_title: AutoFlight unveils world’s largest flying car as China races to lead low-altitude economy

images.alt: Passenger aircraft accounts for 70 per cent of AutoFlight’s total orders. Photo: Handout
images.title: Passenger aircraft accounts for 70 per cent of AutoFlight’s total orders. Photo: Handout

items.content:
Chinese aviation start-up AutoFlight, backed by electric vehicle (EV) battery giant Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), is emblematic of mainland China’s ambitions in the flying car market, part of the country’s broader push to dominate the low-altitude economy.
The Shanghai-based company on Thursday unveiled Matrix, a five-tonne (11,000lbs) class electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft, which it described as the largest of its kind in the world after completing a flight...

items.title: China’s Year of the Horse shoppers let emotional satisfaction take the reins
items.creator: Zhu Wenqian
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s Year of the Horse shoppers let emotional satisfaction take the reins

images.alt: Pet retailer Popocola sold 1,000 units of a festival-themed vest for dogs in 30 days. Photo: Handout
images.title: Pet retailer Popocola sold 1,000 units of a festival-themed vest for dogs in 30 days. Photo: Handout

items.content:
As the Year of the Horse approaches, Chinese consumers are hunting online for mascots, dolls and charms themed after the zodiac animal, favouring soft, round and playful designs over formal styles, in what industry observers say places more weight on emotional fulfilment than on material possessions or brand prestige.
This craze is boosting retail sales for plush toys and gold accessories, as is evident in toymaker Pop Mart’s sold-out Have a Good Run series of plush pendants, as well as brisk...

items.title: Why Tesla fell behind BYD, and why catching up won’t be easy
items.creator: Mark Greeven
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Why Tesla fell behind BYD, and why catching up won’t be easy

images.alt: BYD hybrid and electric vehicles shipped from China are parked at Terminal Zarate in Argentina’s Buenos Aires province on January 20. BYD’s vertical integration model means it can bring new models to market faster and slash production costs, keeping prices lower than its rivals. Photo: AP
images.title: BYD hybrid and electric vehicles shipped from China are parked at Terminal Zarate in Argentina’s Buenos Aires province on January 20. BYD’s vertical integration model means it can bring new models to market faster and slash production costs, keeping prices lower than its rivals. Photo: AP

items.content:
China’s BYD has pulled ahead of Tesla, becoming the world’s biggest maker of fully electric vehicles (EVs). The shift reflects more than the fortunes of the two companies. Tesla’s dethroning shows how China’s EV sector, built around dense supplier networks, fast iteration and strong policy support, is setting the pace for the rest of the world.
The shift is even more notable considering that BYD was barely known outside China a decade ago. Now BYD is outpacing its competitors, delivering more...

items.title: China’s software sector braces for spillover from AI-led global sell-off
items.creator: Wency Chen
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s software sector braces for spillover from AI-led global sell-off
items.content:
Fears that increasingly capable AI agents pose existential threats to the traditional software business have rippled through global equity markets, triggering a sharp sell-off in US software stocks this week and spilling over to China’s software-as-a-service (SaaS) sector.
Analysts say the impact on China could be just as profound, but shaped by different structural dynamics.
“SaaS growth in China in the next few years will be driven by several leading companies in cloud services and AI –...

items.translated_title: China tightens crypto crackdown with onshore RWA tokenisation ban

images.alt: The notice was issued by eight government agencies led by the People’s Bank of China. Photo: China News Service/VCG via Getty Images
images.title: The notice was issued by eight government agencies led by the People’s Bank of China. Photo: China News Service/VCG via Getty Images

items.content:
Chinese authorities issued a notice on Friday that tightened regulations on virtual currency trading, expanding Beijing’s crackdown on cryptocurrencies to the tokenisation of real world assets (RWA).
Onshore RWA tokenisation activities and related intermediary or technology services for securities issuance, financial operations or fundraising were banned, according to the notice, which added that exceptions may apply in specific cases if approved by authorities.
“Overseas entities and...

items.title: Tesla launches China AI training centre as self-driving race accelerates

items.translated_title: Tesla launches China AI training centre as self-driving race accelerates

images.alt: Tesla rolled out its Full Self-Driving navigation software in mainland China in February last year. Photo: AFP
images.title: Tesla rolled out its Full Self-Driving navigation software in mainland China in February last year. Photo: AFP

items.content:
Tesla has begun operating a China-focused artificial intelligence training centre to enhance its cars’ self-driving capabilities in the world’s largest electric vehicle (EV) market, following Beijing’s deregulation of the technology.
Grace Tao, vice-president of Tesla, told Shanghai-based financial news outlet Cailian on Friday that the centre had sufficient computing power to support development of assisted-driving features. However, she did not disclose details such as the centre’s location or...

items.title: China fines firms for fake ChatGPT and DeepSeek services in IP theft crackdown (原标题: China fines firms for fake ChatGPT and DeepSeek services amid tightening AI governance)
items.creator: Iris Deng
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China fines firms for fake ChatGPT and DeepSeek services in IP theft crackdown

images.alt: The companies operating knock-off services of DeepSeek and ChatGPT violated China’s Anti-Unfair Competition Law, according to authorities. AFP
images.title: The companies operating knock-off services of DeepSeek and ChatGPT violated China’s Anti-Unfair Competition Law, according to authorities. AFP

items.content:
China’s market regulator has penalised several companies for posing as DeepSeek and OpenAI’s ChatGPT to defraud users, in its latest crackdown on unfair competition in the fast-growing artificial intelligence sector.
The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR), China’s market watchdog, fined Shanghai Shangyun Internet Technology 62,692.70 yuan (US$9,034) for operating a fraudulent ChatGPT service on Tencent Holdings’ super app WeChat.
The service posed as the official Chinese version...

items.title: Alibaba’s bubble tea giveaway pushes Qwen past Tencent’s Yuanbao to top of China App Store

items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Alibaba’s bubble tea giveaway pushes Qwen past Tencent’s Yuanbao to top of China App Store

images.alt: Alibaba achieved two goals with one campaign, according to analysts. Photo: Shutterstock
images.title: Alibaba achieved two goals with one campaign, according to analysts. Photo: Shutterstock

items.content:
Hours after Alibaba Group Holding began offering freebies including bubble tea through its artificial intelligence app Qwen on Friday, a surge in downloads pushed the chatbot past Tencent Holdings’ Yuanbao to the top of China’s Apple App Store, climbing from 10th place a day earlier.
More than 10 million free orders – worth 250 million yuan (US$36 million) – were placed within nine hours using vouchers capped at 25 yuan through Qwen, its team said on its official Weibo account.
The surge in...

items.title: Watchdog slaps China’s Kuaishou with US$17 million fine after explicit content probe
items.creator: Iris Deng
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Watchdog slaps China’s Kuaishou with US$17 million fine after explicit content probe
items.content:
China’s internet watchdog has fined Kuaishou Technology 119.1 million yuan (US$17 million) for hosting explicit live-streaming content, just days after the operator of the country’s second-largest short-video platform was penalised over e-commerce violations.
Beijing’s Cyberspace Administration launched an investigation following reports of a surge in pornographic and vulgar streams.
The probe found the platform had failed to meet its cybersecurity obligations, fix system vulnerabilities in...

items.title: Fosun Pharma’s US$1.55 billion Eisai deal signals shift to long-term partnerships
items.creator: Julie Zhang
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: Fosun Pharma’s US$1.55 billion Eisai deal signals shift to long-term partnerships

images.alt: The Fosun Pharma pavilion at the China International Import Expo, November 6, 2026. Photo: Daniel Ren
images.title: The Fosun Pharma pavilion at the China International Import Expo, November 6, 2026. Photo: Daniel Ren

items.content:
A unit of Fosun Pharma has struck a US$1.55 billion deal to license its home-grown cancer drug to Japan’s Eisai, adding to a wave of out-licensing agreements that are channelling billions of dollars into Chinese novel drug development.
The deal comes as Chinese novel drug makers are having more say in how their new medicines are developed with global partners, shifting from simple one-off licensing fees, where a company is paid for granting rights to its drug, to long-term collaborations.
Under...

items.title: China trials its largest locally made AI computing resource in major infrastructure push

items.translated_title: China trials its largest locally made AI computing resource in major infrastructure push

images.alt: Based on the performance of a single Sugon scaleX, the three platforms could deliver a combined computing power of 15 eflops. Photo: Handout
images.title: Based on the performance of a single Sugon scaleX, the three platforms could deliver a combined computing power of 15 eflops. Photo: Handout

items.content:
China’s state-backed SuperComputing Network (SCNet), a major computing resource provider, has deployed a new node for beta testing, powered by the country’s largest domestically made artificial intelligence computing cluster.
The node, which began trial runs on Thursday in Zhengzhou, central Henan province, consists of three scaleX platforms from Chinese supercomputer developer Sugon, which support the deployment of more than 30,000 AI acceleration cards, according to statements from both SCNet...

items.title: China’s humanoid robot makers pivot from ‘body’ to ‘brain’ as commercial race heats up
items.creator: Iris Deng
items.summary: 无法生成摘要（API请求失败）。
items.translated_title: China’s humanoid robot makers pivot from ‘body’ to ‘brain’ as commercial race heats up
items.content:
Chinese humanoid robotics companies are doubling down on developing intelligent models, as investors eye advances in robot “brains” as the next step towards real-world commercial use.
Shenzhen-based Dobot said on Wednesday that it delivered its third batch of mass produced, full-size humanoid Atom robots, marking a shift from laboratory concept to an industrialised product.
Dobot, listed in Hong Kong, said its self-developed Dobot-VLA, a vision-language-action model, enabled Atom to react to...

items.title: Space-computing push of Elon Musk’s SpaceX shines beam on China’s solar supply chain

items.translated_title: Space-computing push of Elon Musk’s SpaceX shines beam on China’s solar supply chain

images.alt: China’s new photovoltaic installations are forecast to reach up to 240 gigawatts in 2026. Photo: Getty Images
images.title: China’s new photovoltaic installations are forecast to reach up to 240 gigawatts in 2026. Photo: Getty Images

items.content:
Elon Musk’s SpaceX has been sounding out multiple Chinese solar suppliers in recent weeks, industry insiders and companies confirmed, as the world’s richest man advances his vision for space-based data centres powered by constant solar energy – drawing fresh attention to China’s solar supply chain.
The discussions, which have not yet resulted in confirmed orders, triggered a rally in shares of several solar-related companies earlier this week, before sentiment cooled on Thursday.
Analysts and...

items.translated_title: Cyberport rolls out one-stop ‘ABC Service Centre’

images.alt: Above: Daniel Cheung, deputy commissioner (digital infrastructure) at the Digital Policy Office, delivers opening remarks at the launch of the Cyberport ABC Service Centre in Hong Kong on Monday. Below: Simon Chan, chairman of Cyberport, speaks at the event.
images.title: Above: Daniel Cheung, deputy commissioner (digital infrastructure) at the Digital Policy Office, delivers opening remarks at the launch of the Cyberport ABC Service Centre in Hong Kong on Monday. Below: Simon Chan, chairman of Cyberport, speaks at the event.

images.alt: Cyberport signs a memorandum of understanding with Hillstone Networks to support cybersecurity training and technical collaboration. The signing is witnessed by Daniel Cheung, deputy commissioner (digital infrastructure) at the Digital Policy Office (back row, centre), Simon Chan, chairman of Cyberport (back row, left), and Haiqiang Ye, chairman and chief executive of Hillstone Networks (back row, right). The agreement is signed by Dr Rocky Cheng, chief executive of Cyberport (front row, left), and Max Zhao, vice-president and head of overseas business at Hillstone Networks (front row, right).
images.title: Cyberport signs a memorandum of understanding with Hillstone Networks to support cybersecurity training and technical collaboration. The signing is witnessed by Daniel Cheung, deputy commissioner (digital infrastructure) at the Digital Policy Office (back row, centre), Simon Chan, chairman of Cyberport (back row, left), and Haiqiang Ye, chairman and chief executive of Hillstone Networks (back row, right). The agreement is signed by Dr Rocky Cheng, chief executive of Cyberport (front row, left), and Max Zhao, vice-president and head of overseas business at Hillstone Networks (front row, right).

images.alt: Cyberport signs a memorandum of understanding with Hong Kong ICI Cloud Service Limited to support the establishment of the Cyberport AI Factory. The signing is witnessed by Daniel Cheung, deputy commissioner (digital infrastructure) at the Digital Policy Office (back row, centre), Simon Chan, chairman of Cyberport (back row, left), and Ivy Yin, chairwoman of ICI Cloud (back row, right). The agreement is signed by Dr Rocky Cheng, chief executive of Cyberport (front row, left), and Mark Xing, general manager of ICI Cloud (front row, right).
images.title: Cyberport signs a memorandum of understanding with Hong Kong ICI Cloud Service Limited to support the establishment of the Cyberport AI Factory. The signing is witnessed by Daniel Cheung, deputy commissioner (digital infrastructure) at the Digital Policy Office (back row, centre), Simon Chan, chairman of Cyberport (back row, left), and Ivy Yin, chairwoman of ICI Cloud (back row, right). The agreement is signed by Dr Rocky Cheng, chief executive of Cyberport (front row, left), and Mark Xing, general manager of ICI Cloud (front row, right).

images.alt: Industry representatives from FizzDragon, Biren Technology, ICI Cloud and DAS-Security International take part in a discussion on AI development and cross-sector applications during the opening event of the Cyberport ABC Service Centre.
images.title: Industry representatives from FizzDragon, Biren Technology, ICI Cloud and DAS-Security International take part in a discussion on AI development and cross-sector applications during the opening event of the Cyberport ABC Service Centre.

items.content:
[The content of this article has been produced by our advertising partner.]
 
Cyberport has launched a new technology platform to better support the adoption of AI across Hong Kong’s research and development sector, as the city continues to build out its digital infrastructure for advanced technologies.
One-Stop Platform Driving Innovation From Idea to Rollout
Unveiled on January 26, Cyberport  ABC Service Centre brings together A (artificial intelligence), B (big data) and C (cybersecurity)...
